State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (Beijing) 18 Fuxue Road Beijing 102249 PR China Graphical abstract With the peak in diesel consumption and the impact of new energy in the coming years, research will be focused on the treatment of excess diesel. In addition, low carbon aromatics such as benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) are important chemical raw materials that will be in high demand in the next few years but are still in short supply. Thus, many researchers have proposed the use of excess diesel, especially the inferior diesel-like light cycle oil (LCO) to produce BTX. The hydrocracking process is typically used to convert LCO to BTX. To provide some guidance on this topic, this review summarizes the typical group compositions in LCO from different refineries, hydrocracking reaction mechanisms of aromatics and cycloalkanes in LCO, hydrocracking catalysts, improved hydrocracking conditions, related hydrocracking technologies, and future developments in the production of BTX. The amount of aromatics with different ring numbers in LCO has been clearly analyzed, and their part types have also been studied. However, some complex types of aromatics in LCO remain unknown. In addition, the hydrocracking mechanisms and pathways of aromatics in LCO to produce BTX have garnered great attention since the 1990s. Based on this, hydrocracking catalysts and related technologies have been developed by many institutions and corporations to convert aromatics to BTX; however, there are still some problems including an insufficient selectivity of BTX, low yield of liquid products, and excessive energy consumption. In the future, more advanced technologies can be applied to analyze all types of aromatics in LCO, which, along with the aid and application of computational chemistry tools, could help deepen the understanding of the reaction pathways of aromatics and develop more efficient catalysts by balancing the properties of the active phase and supporting the surmounting of current shortcomings. Owing to this high value utilization of inferior diesel, the upcoming problem of diesel surplus can be solved effectively, and the utilization of LCO to produce BTX is one possible path. Keywords Inferior diesel LCO BTX Reaction mechanism Catalysts Technology 1 Introduction In recent years, the output of refined oil has increased significantly with increases in the refinement capacity of many countries. However, a problem arises with this improvement in petroleum product production. That is, the worldwide production of diesel will be excessive in the next few years. At the same time, petroleum resources are becoming increasingly tight. Moreover, the rise of new energy has had a huge impact on traditional fuel oil; thus, fully treating the coming excessive diesel is a key point in the rational utilization of resources [1]. Catalytic diesel, especially for light cycle oil (LCO), which is the light diesel fraction from catalytic cracking units, is a typical inferior diesel because it has high sulfur (up to 40000 ppm), nitrogen (higher than 600 ppm), and aromatic (up to 90 wt%) contents and a low cetane number (approximately 27, far less than the lowest standard, which is 51 in America) [2–4]. SOx and NOx are formed when sulfur and nitrogen compounds are burned in engines, which leads to air pollution and shortens the life of the engine [5]. In addition, aromatics not only decrease the cetane number of diesel but also increase the difficulty and energy consumption of other relative pretreatment processes for the inferior diesel [6]. Environmental protection has recently become a vital issue in industrial production. Thus, a new standard for commercial diesel has been implemented in many countries and regions [7–10], which further limits the content of aromatics in LCO, especially that of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), because their existence in inferior diesel will increase particulate emissions when burned and simultaneously decrease the stability, ignition performance, combustion performance, and cetane number of the diesel [11]. In conclusion, the industrial structure must be adjusted to realize a high value and clean utilization of LCO. Low-carbon aromatics such as benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) are important chemical raw materials, and their demand will continue to increase in the coming years [12,13]. The worldwide increase in paraxylene (PX) demand, for example, will remain at a rate of 3.5 % over the next five years, especially in the Asia-Pacific region, because it is a major producer of plastics and synthetic fibers [14]. Because of the increasing demand for downstream products, the BTX growth rate of need is much higher than the demand for refined oil [15]. The high content of potential aromatics in LCO and its inferior properties make it a good candidate for the production of light aromatics. Therefore, upgrading LCO to BTX through hydrocracking has attracted great interest as chemical materials are currently more valuable than liquid fuels [16]. To optimize a refinery’s product distribution, the use of the surplus diesel capacity to increase the production of chemical materials such as BTX, which are in short supply, and to realize the high value utilization of diesel has become a hot research topic. In 2016, Laredo et al. [14] presented a review of the hydrocracking process for obtaining fuel-enriched BTX from model mixtures under different experimental conditions and summarized the distribution of products after hydrocracking using different catalysts. In the same year, Galadima et al. [17] reviewed the design of suitable catalysts for the hydrocracking of PAHs in LCO and the production of light aromatics. Another review, also written by Laredo and his colleagues in 2018 [18], presented related content about using LCO to produce BTX. They clearly summarized the hydrotreating-hydrocracking procedure for producing light aromatics from real feed. However, the reaction mechanism and catalysts have not been systematically demonstrated, especially for catalysts. It is widely acknowledged that the properties of catalysts, such as acidity, porosity, and metal properties, exert a prominent influence on the reaction. It is worth mentioning that most of the current research is primarily focused on these areas [19–21]. To clarify the entire LCO hydrocracking process to produce BTX, starting from an analysis of the properties of LCO, this paper systematically reviews the current high-value technologies to produce BTX from diesel from the aspects of reaction mechanism, catalysts, improved conditions, and technical advantages and disadvantages, and further analyzes the key points for the future development of these technologies, which may help researchers to understand the current status in this area. 2 Hydrocracking reaction 2.1 Components in LCO The physical properties and chemical compositions of LCO produced by different refineries vary. Table 1 shows the physical properties and composition of LCO from the three refineries [22–24]. It can be seen that the components in LCO can be classified into alkanes, cycloalkanes, aromatics, and impurities (sulfur and nitrogen compounds). It is worth mentioning that the aromatic content of LCO is higher than 60 wt%, which significantly reduces the quality and cetane number of commercial diesel after blending [25]. Moreover, there are relatively high amounts of sulfur (higher than 0.05 wt%) and nitrogen (higher than 0.086 wt%) in LCO, which pollutes the environment when it is burned. In addition, the existence of nitrogen compounds (especially basic nitrogen compounds) leads to the inactivation of catalysts because the catalysts used in hydrocracking usually possess acidic properties [26–28]. Many researchers [29–31] have analyzed the distribution of aromatics with different cyclic numbers in LCO, and the results are shown in Table 2 . It is obvious that mono-aromatics and di-aromatics constitute most of the aromatics in LCO and that the mono-aromatic side chain can be easily broken to generate light aromatics. Therefore, the conversion of di-aromatics to BTX has become the main challenge for researchers. In addition, the di-aromatic types in LCO have been evaluated by some scholars [32–34] using gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC–MS) or other technologies. It can be seen from Table 3 that the di-aromatics in LCO are mainly composed of naphthalene and its derivatives, of which methylnaphthalene consists most, so they are usually used as model compounds by researchers when studying hydrocracking. In addition, phenanthrene, anthracene, and their derivatives are the typical tri-aromatics; thus, many scholars are also studying their hydrocracking. In summary, LCO is a typical inferior diesel, and it has many potential aromatics from which to produce BTX. It is worthy studying the hydrocracking mechanism of its components, especially the di-aromatics, and the effect of nitrogen compounds on hydrocracking catalysts to maximize the productivity of BTX. 2.2 Effects of nitrogen compounds on the hydrocracking reaction The catalysts used in the process of hydrocracking are mainly bifunctional catalysts that consist of an active phase and support, which is usually a molecular sieve with acid sites [35,36]. It is well known that organic nitrogen, especially the basic nitrogen compounds in LCO, has a strong adsorption effect on the acid center of supports [37], which leads to a deactivation of the catalysts. Thus, the nitrogen content of the feedstock should be strictly limited. To protect hydrocracking catalysts, it is of great significance to study the influence of nitrogen compounds, the understanding of which can provide direct theoretical guidance for the development of new nitrogen compound-resistant hydrocracking catalysts. Until now, studies on the influence of nitrogen compounds on catalysts have mainly focused on two aspects. The adsorption properties of different types of organic nitrogen on hydrocracking catalysts have been studied. Nitrogen compounds are broadly classified into three categories, as shown in Table 4 [38]. The results of GC–MS, et al. showed that indoles and carbazoles account for the majority of LCO, while anilines and quinolines constitute a small part [39]. Because hydrocracking catalysts have acid sites, basic organic nitrogen could exert a strong inhibitory effect on the catalysts [40–42]. Typically, basic organic nitrogen is first converted to NH3, which is less basic, by hydrotreatment. Several studies have found a substantial reduction in the activity of molecular sieve catalysts in the presence of NH3 [43–45] by the neutralization of Brønsted acid sites. This is because the adsorption of nitrogen-containing molecules on Brønsted acid sites is stronger than that of hydrocarbons [46,47]. Research by Mendes et al. [48] also proved this result, and they found that the fraction of Brønsted acid sites that was inhibited was larger than 98 % because of the adsorption of NH3, indicating that the Brønsted acid sites are nearly saturated by NH3 molecules when using NiMo/USY catalysts in hydrocracking vacuum gas oil. Moreover, Lee et al. [49] found that an increase in the concentration of Lewis acid sites helps to improve the resistance to poisoning by nitrogen compounds when using Pt–Mg/ZSM-23 and Pt–Pd–Mg/ZSM-23 to hydrocrack n-hexadecane. Thus, basic organic nitrogen seems to have a larger influence on Brønsted acid sites than Lewis acid sites. However, the hydrocracking reaction usually requires a relatively strong Brønsted acid; therefore, it is desirable to remove the basic nitrogen compounds from the feed before hydrocracking. Some studies on the inhibition of neutral organic nitrogen compounds have been reported [50,51]. Laredo et al. [51] reported that the inhibiting effect of non-basic compounds is also very strong, even at concentrations as low as 5 ppm. This is because these nitrogen compounds directly absorb on the hydrocracking catalyst in the reaction without being converted to NH3. The influence mechanism of nitrogen compounds on the hydrocracking reaction can be further understood by studying the reaction performance of nitrogen compounds on different catalysts. Scherzer and Butt et al. [52] attributed the poisoning of hydrocracking catalysts to the deactivation of the active metals caused by the adsorption of nitrogen compounds on the active phase of the catalysts. Corma et al. [53] studied the poisoning mechanism of alkaline nitrogen compounds on hydrocracking catalysts and reported that alkaline nitrogen compounds are not only adsorbed on the acid center but also induce the adsorption of other alkaline nitrogen compounds, leading to a deactivation of the catalyst. To prevent the catalysts from being poisoned by nitrogen compounds, a hydrotreating process is often used to remove the nitrogen compounds from the feed. However, aromatics are usually significantly saturated by traditional hydrogenation, leading to a loss of BTX yield. For example, Betancourt et al. [54] used NiMoV series catalysts to remove nitrogen compounds from LCO by hydrotreating. The results showed that although approximately 95 % of the nitrogen compounds were removed, nearly 33 % of the aromatics were saturated after the hydrotreatment process. Ding et al. [55] used a hydrotreating process to decrease the content of nitrogen compounds from 495.6 ppm to as low as 1.45 ppm; however, the mass fraction of aromatics in LCO decreased from 72.8 % to 87.6 %. The same phenomenon has also been observed in other studies [56–58]. From these studies, it was found that the aromatics will suffer a loss through the hydrotreating process to remove the nitrogen compounds from LCO. In fact, aromatics are inevitably saturated during the hydrotreatment process. To avoid such a loss, some researchers have developed nitrogen-compound-resistant catalysts to convert LCO to BTX without a hydrotreating process, and these catalysts are clearly introduced in Section 3.3. In conclusion, nitrogen compounds have a significant influence on hydrocracking catalysts. Although the types and reaction mechanisms of nitrogen compounds on the catalysts have been well studied, catalysts being developed to resist the nitrogen compounds are still in laboratory research; therefore, the LCO used to produce BTX still requires hydrotreating to remove the nitrogen compounds, which adds to the cost and complexity of the entire process. In the future, more nitrogen-compound-resistant catalysts should be developed to help produce BTX. In the development of catalysts, researchers should pay more attention to the protection of Brønsted acid from poisoning by nitrogen compounds. 2.3 Hydrocracking reaction network of components to produce BTX 2.3.1 Hydrocracking reaction network of aromatics to produce BTX Studies on the reaction mechanism and pathways of reactants can maximize the yields of ideal products. Control of the direction of the reaction also helps to reduce its energy consumption. Aromatics are the main resource in LCO to produce BTX; therefore, research on the reaction network of aromatics to produce BTX is important. The content of PAHs in LCO is higher than that of monocyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (MAHs) [59]; therefore, studies on the hydrocracking of aromatics to BTX mainly consider PAHs (such as naphthalene, anthracene, and phenanthrene) as model compounds [60–62]. The hydrocracking reaction of PAHs to BTX is an essentially catalytic cracking carbocation reaction, and it generally includes hydrogenation, isomerization, hydrogen transfer, ring opening, cracking, and dehydrogenation condensation coking, in which the hydrogenation and cracking reactions are predominant [63]. Next, the hydrocracking mechanism and pathways of bicyclic and tricyclic aromatic hydrocarbons are introduced. Diaromatics (mainly including naphthalene and its derivatives) are the major constituent of PAHs; therefore, the hydrocracking network of diaromatics is fundamentally considered by researchers [64–66]. Choi et al. [67] used naphthalene as a model compound to describe the hydrogenation and hydrocracking reactions of bicyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, as shown in Fig. 1 . To produce BTX from naphthalene hydrocracking, it is necessary to hydrogenate naphthalene to tetralin. Then, the tetralin is converted to BTX by hydrocracking. The side reaction is that tetralin can be further hydrogenated to decalin and then cracked to diesel, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and naphtha. Calemma et al. [68] also believed that naphthalene could be hydrogenated to tetralin, and tetralin could be further hydrogenated to decalin, or it could be opened to form alkylbenzene, LPG, and naphtha. Infantes-Molina et al. [69] reported the first generation of tetralin in the hydrogenation and hydrocracking of naphthalene. To study the subsequent path of the tetralin hydrocracking reaction, Corma et al. [70] studied the cracking and hydrogenation of tetralin. From their research, hydrocracking tetralin reactions include dealkylation, transalkylation, isomerization, cracking, and hydrogen transfer reactions, of which the cracking reaction obeys the carbon ion reaction mechanism. The literature [71] affirmed that the tetralin hydrocracking reaction can be initiated by bimolecular and unimolecular mechanisms, of which the former accounts for the formation of phenylbutyl tetralin (PBT). At a relatively high temperature, the formation of PBT is negligible, and, as a result, the unimolecular mechanism takes charge, covering the attack of a Brønsted site on the aromatic ring [72] or naphthenic ring [73,74]. The opening of the naphthenic ring to form alkenyl and alkyl-benzenes can be explained by the β-Scission and protolytic cracking reactions of the resultant carbenium and carbonium ions. Ferraz et al. [75] also proved that the cracking of the naphthenic ring opening begins at the β position. It is worth mentioning that the isomerization reaction can be initiated through the PCP mechanism [76], which may account for the contraction of the ring and formation of methylindanes and methylindenes. In conclusion, the β-Scission reaction is key for producing alkyl benzene and further generating BTX in the hydrocracking of tetralin. The hydrocracking network of tetralin, illustrated by Corma et al., is shown in Fig. 2 . For naphthalene derivatives, the hydrocracking mechanism and pathway of methylnaphthalene have been studied by many researchers. Miki et al. [77] clearly illustrated the reaction pathways of 1-methylnaphthalene and 2-methylnaphthalene. The results showed that the hydrocracking of methylnaphthalene involves a series of complex parallel reactions with more than 100 products, mainly including the following six types: (1) isomerization products; (2) partial hydrogenation products: methyl tetrahydronaphthalene and its isomers; (3) complete hydrogenation products: methyl decarbonaphthalene and its isomers; (4) ring-opening products: C11 alkyl benzene; (5) broken side chain after ring-opening products: low-carbon alkyl benzene; (6) isomerization and ring-unopened products: indene and alkyl-substituted indene. The entire methylnaphthalene pathway is shown in Fig. 3 . Park et al. [78] pointed out that the benzene ring without methyl is first hydrogenated because of the low steric stabilization. Then, hydrogenation and hydrocracking reactions occur on the hydrogenated products to form saturated hydrocarbons of methyl benzene. Wu et al. [79] believed that there is a transition state with a five-membered ring between the hydrogenated products and alkyl benzene, which is similar to the pathway of hydrocracking tetralin through the PCP mechanism. Moreover, some studies [80,81] proved that the hydrogenation of the first benzene ring in PAHs (e.g., naphthalene, 1-methylnaphthalene) is thermodynamically more likely to occur than the hydrogenation saturation of a single cyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (e.g., tetrahydronaphthalene, ninhydrin, and alkylbenzene). As expected, the first step was observed during the hydrogenation of methylnaphthalene, and naphthalene hydrogenation followed a similar pathway. Currently, it is generally believed that the hydrocracking reaction of tricyclic aromatics (such as anthracene, phenanthrene, and their homologs) also occurs in stages. The hydrogenation reaction of phenanthrene has been studied since 1990 [82–85]. The hydrogenation network of phenanthrene can be divided into three types: reaction network 1 proposed by Beltramone et al. [86], reaction network 2 proposed by Korre et al. [87], and reaction network 3 proposed by Qian et al. [88], as shown in Fig. 4 . From their research, it was found that the hydrogenation reaction of phenanthrene is a reversible reaction, and hydrogenation products are converted between the five substances (left-side pathway shown in Fig. 4). For the hydrocracking reaction of phenanthrene, Celis-Cornejo et al. [89] studied the three hydrocracking reaction paths of phenanthrene: (1) hydrocracking of the middle ring, (2) isomerization, ring-opening, and cracking of phenanthrene through complete hydrogenation; and (3) hydrocracking of the side ring. Phenanthrene is prioritized in the third reaction pathway; that is, one of the side rings of phenanthrene is hydrogenated and then cracked to generate dicyclic aromatics, or both end rings are hydrogenated and then cracked to generate monocyclic aromatics (right-side pathway shown in Fig. 4). It is a pity that no further hydrogenation and cracking reactions were introduced to form a total hydrocracking network of hydrophenanthrene to produce BTX. Anthracene is another type of tricyclic aromatic hydrocarbon that is typically used to research hydrocracking networks. The hydrogenation and cracking of anthracene involve three pathways. Pinilla et al. [90,91] found that anthracene can be translated to biphenyl by turning the middle ring into a transition state, or it can be translated to naphthalene by the hydrogenation and cracking of the side ring, as shown in Fig. 5 . Han et al. [92] thought that the middle ring of anthracene could be directly hydrogenated and cracked to form alkyl benzene, and Liu et al. [93] and Zhang et al. [94] used different catalyst systems to prove the existence of the ring-opening reaction after the hydrogenation of the middle ring. Obviously, the pathway of the middle ring hydrogenation and cracking consumes the least amount of hydrogen. Therefore, if the catalytic reaction process of anthracene can be accurately controlled, it can improve the yield of BTX and greatly reduce the consumption of hydrogen and energy. 2.3.2 Hydrocracking reaction network of cycloalkane to help to produce BTX It is of great importance to study the hydrocracking reaction mechanism of cycloalkanes because the PAHs will be hydrogenated to the corresponding cycloalkane before cracking to BTX. The study of the hydrocracking network of cycloalkanes can help researchers to develop catalysts for hydrocracking PAHs to BTX, and their hydrocracking mechanism has been studied for many years. For different carbon numbers of the one-ring cycloalkane, it is recognized that the inner stress of the ternary and quaternary rings is high, and the ring opening can easily occur. The study found that the internal stress of the five-membered ring cycloalkane is 6–7 kcal/mol and that of the six-membered ring cycloalkane is 1 kcal/mol, which indicates that the six-membered ring cycloalkane is relatively stable. The sequence of internal stress in different ring numbers of cycloalkanes is C3 > C4 > > C5–C7 > > C6 [95]. Al-sabawi et al. [96,97] studied the reaction of cyclohexane on auria-acid bifunctional catalysts, and they considered that the acid sites promote the isomerism of six-membered rings to five-membered rings, followed by an acceleration of the ring-opening reaction. On the acid supports, a six-membered ring on the Brønsted sites of the support carry forward the plasmolysis (PC), which follows the positive carbon ion mechanism, and then develops the contraction ring (RC), which is the cracking reaction [70]. The reaction mechanism and pathway of the one-ring cycloalkane are the same as those of the ring-opening reaction of tetralin to produce BTX. To further study the reaction pathway of the cycloalkane mechanism, the hydrocracking pathway of dicyclic cycloalkanes, whose structure is similar to that of naphthalene, has been studied. The ring-opening reaction of the double-ring cycloalkane was found to be more effective for bifunctional catalysts [98,99]. In addition, the ring-opening reaction of dicyclic cycloalkanes follows the positive carbon ion mechanism, which is identical to the hydrocracking of tetralin to produce BTX. Kubicka et al. [100] clearly discussed the hydrogenation and ring-opening reactions of decalin molecules on bifunctional catalysts and proposed a reaction pathway, as shown in Fig. 6 . As shown in the reaction process in Fig. 6, decalin undergoes a series of reactions during hydrocracking. The dehydrogenation of decalin on the metal site first forms an olefin before desorption, then moves to the nearby acid site to form positive carbon ions. The formed positive carbon ions undergo skeleton isomerization, hydrogen transfer, olefin desorption-adsorption, β-fracture, and ring opening. The product leaves the acid site and moves to the metal site for hydrogenation, and finally detaches from the catalyst. In addition, the ring-opening products can only be detected when the isomerization reaction is carried out, which indicates that the initial reaction of the hydrocracking process of decalin is the isomerization reaction, and the subsequent reaction is the ring-opening reaction. Their research showed that the isomerization reaction of decalin plays an important role in the initial reaction. The same results were reported by Kangas et al. [101], who studied the reaction path of the decalin open-loop reaction under a bifunctional catalyst (Pt/H-Beta), modeled the open-loop reaction, and proposed the relevant reaction path. The model shows that the ring-opening products are mainly generated by the isomers of decalin. The main intermediate in the open-ring reaction is the 2-D shrinkage isomer, and the isomer with the highest activation energy is the 3-D isomer. Al-sabawi et al. [102] theoretically proved that the isomerization reaction plays an important role in the initial reaction. It is clear that the hydrocracking reaction networks of naphthalene, methylnaphthalene, and tetralin to produce BTX have been fully studied. However, side reactions such as coking are rarely taken into consideration, as the entire reaction networks of the di-aromatics have not been proposed; therefore, research on molecular dynamics and lump kinetics is rare. In future research, more studies that combine the reaction network and kinetics could be considered for researchers to design the catalysts more reasonably. Catalysts play an important role in catalytic reactions. The development of suitable catalysts (including adjustments in acid and pores) can facilitate the hydrocracking reaction proceeding in the desired direction according to the reaction networks. In the next section, we introduce the catalysts currently used in the hydrocracking of aromatics to produce BTX. 3 Development of hydrocracking catalysts 3.1 Catalyst components Generally, the catalysts used are bifunctional owing to hydrogenation and crack activity and are mainly composed of an active phase and support. The components of the hydrocracking catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The hydrogenation activity of the catalyst mainly comes from the active phase, and it can also stabilize the acid sites [103,104], which can be divided into precious metals (Pt, Pd, etc.) and non-precious metals (metal oxides or sulfides of group VIB and VIII elements). Acid sites are the source of the cracking and isomerization activity of hydrocracking catalysts and are mainly provided by supports (usually molecular sieves such as Y, Beta, et al.). The supports include weak acid and acid supports, which mainly have the functions of increasing the effective surface area of the catalysts to attach the reactants, providing an appropriate pore structure for reactants and products, offering acid centers to realize the cracking reaction, improving the mechanical strength and thermal stability of the catalyst, and increasing the anti-toxic ability of the catalyst [70]. The weak acid support is mainly oxide alumina, and the acid supports are aluminum silicate, magnesium silicate, and some kinds of molecular sieves, which are often used together to regulate the acid properties of catalysts [105]. It is worth mentioning that molecular sieves with medium and strong acids are generally used as supports for the hydrocracking of aromatic hydrocarbons. In addition, some types of additives are often used to improve the dispersity of the active phase on the supports, modify the acid properties, and improve the pore structure of the catalysts. To achieve selective hydrogenation and cracking reactions, the active phase and support of the catalyst must be well matched [106]. 3.2 Active phase To obtain a high BTX yield, it is necessary to control the hydrogenation depth of the catalysts. The main factors affecting the hydrogenation depth are the type and amount of metal, the bimetallic ratio, and the dispersion state of the metal on the support. The hydrogenation activity of metals is most closely related to their type and chemical properties, because the electronic properties of metals determine the binding strength between the reactants and surface metal atoms. The metals used in hydrocracking include noble metals and non-noble metals [107,108]. 3.2.1 Noble metal catalyst Noble metals such as Pt, Pd, Ru, and Rh have been used in the hydrocracking of PAHs for many years. The carbon-carbon double bond of aromatic molecules can be activated by noble metals with lattice spacings of 0.36–0.38 nm. These noble metal catalysts are widely used because of their high efficiency in deep hydrogenation [108]. For example, Arribas [109] used Pt as the active phase for hydrocracking tetralin, and a yield of 35 % aromatics could be obtained at 325 °C, 3 MPa, and a H2/tetralin molar ratio of 10. Arribas and Martinez [110] used Pt supported on H-USY with different Si/Al ratios (2.6–27.6) as catalysts to convert methylnaphthalene to low carbon aromatics, and they compared the reaction activity of these catalysts. The results showed that the Pt/H-USY (Si/Al = 6.0) catalyst had a high light aromatic selectivity (approximately 50 %) due to its moderate acidity. Jacquin et al. [111] found that the hydrogenation and cracking activities of naphthalene on Rh and Ru catalysts were higher than those of Pt and Ir at 300 °C, and a relatively high yield of ring-opening products such as alkyl-benzene could be obtained. Noble metals have a higher hydrogenation activity than non-noble metals. Ardakani et al. [112] compared the hydrogenation and ring opening of naphthalene, tetralin, and decalin over Mo2C/HY and Pd/HY catalysts. The results showed that the conversion rates of all reactants on the Pd/HY catalyst were higher than those on the Mo2C/HY catalyst under the same conditions. However, the over-hydrogenation of PAHs to polycycloalkanes occurs because of the high hydrogenation activity of noble metals, which reduces the yield of BTX. Thus, it is desirable to cut the hydrogenation activity of noble metals reasonably. In fact, the introduction of noble metals can modify the acid properties of the supports. Rodriguez-Castellon et al. [113] researched the ring opening reaction of tetralin on a noble metal catalyst supported on ZrO2/SiO2 under the conditions of 350 °C and hydrogen pressure of 6 MPa and found that the acid properties of the catalysts and relative selectivity were closely related to the noble metal. All metals, including Pt, Pd, Rh, and Pd-Pt alloys, could decrease the acidity of the support after loading, and the Pd-Pt alloy could reduce the acid content of the support from 1048 to 778 μmol/g, which was due to the load of metal particles covering the acid sites of the support. With the improved acidity, the catalysts of Pd-Pt alloys supported on ZrO2/SiO2 exhibited better BTX selectivity, and the yield of BTX was 23 %. However, the sulfur content in inferior diesel should be limited when using Pt, Pd, and other noble metals as the active phase, because the noble metals are poisoned by sulfur compounds [114]. In addition, noble metal catalysts used in naphthalene hydrocracking give a high selectivity to decalin rather than tetralin when the conversion rate of naphthalene is high owing to the high hydrogenation activity of noble metals [115–117], which leads to a low yield of BTX. The price of noble metals is high, which limits their application in industry [118]. Thus, non-noble metals have been developed as the active phase owing to their high resistance to sulfur compounds, moderate hydrogenation activity, and low price. 3.2.2 Non-noble metal catalyst Non-noble metal catalysts mainly include supported metal sulfides, nitrogen compounds, carbides, phosphides, and non-supported catalysts [119–121]. Transition metal sulfides are the main active phases of hydrocracking catalysts. Commonly, the transition metals used include Ni, Co, Mo, W, and their mixtures (NiW, NiMo, CoMo, CoW) [122,123]. The main goal of the utilization of non-noble metals is to offer the hydrogenation activity of catalysts and modify the acidity of the supports. The use of a single metal as the active phase can also offer hydrogenation activity, and different amounts of metal have a strong influence on the acid of the supports. Ardakani et al. [124] supported Mo2C on H–Y molecular sieves with different Si/Al ratios. They found that unsupported Mo2C particles were inactive and non-selective. In addition, the ring-opening reaction activity of the H–Y molecular sieve was very low under the same reaction conditions. However, when 7.4 wt% Mo2C was loaded on the H–Y molecular sieve, the yield of ring-opening products reached 33 %. The modified catalyst has a bifunctional effect because the reaction takes place on the Mo2C metal particles and H–Y support. The acid content of the H–Y molecular sieve decreased after loading the Mo2C metal particles. Liu and Smith [125] prepared Mo2C/H–Y catalysts with different amounts of Mo2C (7–27 wt%) using the impregnation method. Naphthalene was used as the reactant, and the activity of the catalyst was investigated at 300 °C and 3 MPa. The acid content of the H–Y molecular sieve decreased from 0.84 mmol/g to 0.32 mmol/g after loading 27 % of Mo2C, and the yield of ring opening products showed a similar downward trend. The main reason for the decrease in acid content is the ion exchange between Mo and the H–Y molecular sieve. Usually, a single metal is not sufficient to offer hydrogenation activity and modify the acid properties of the support, and the metallic function and acidity must be further controlled [126]. Thus, bi-metals such as Ni-Sn, Ni-Mo, Co-Mo, and Ni-W have been developed. Upare et al. [127] studied the synergistic effect of Co addition in a Mo/H-beta catalyst. The total acid content of Mo/H-Beta and CoMo/H-Beta catalysts decreased from 1.36 mmol/g to 1.17 and 1.12 mmol/g, respectively. Therefore, the addition of Co further modified the acidity of the catalyst, which improved the conversion rate of tetralin and the yield of BTX. After the Co modification, the conversion rate of tetralin increased from 93.7 to 99.5 % at 370 °C and 8 MPa. The yield of BTX also increased from 61.1. to 62.6 %. The reasons for the above results were that the introduction of Co enhanced the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst and inhibited the formation of coking products. Lee et al. [128] found that the hydrocracking of tetralin over Ni/H-Beta catalysts was non-selective, and a low yield of BTX but high yields of gas and paraffin products were obtained owing to the strong hydrogenation activity of the catalysts. They added some Sn content to suppress the hydrogenation activity by forming Ni-Sn intermetallic compounds, and the catalysts showed yields of BTX and BTX + C9 aromatics as high as 48.1 wt% and 53.1 wt%, respectively. With the use of a polymetallic catalyst, the effect of non-noble catalysts can be equivalent to that of noble catalysts. Mouli et al. [129] found that the yield of ring-opening products of dechydronaphthene on a NiMoC/HY catalyst was 33.7 % at 240 °C, which was equivalent to that of the Pt-Ir/HY catalyst (about 32 %) at 220 °C. Ni2P is considered to be the most active phosphide for the hydrocracking of PAHs to BTX. Kim et al. [130] found that the conversion rate of naphthalene on the Ni2P catalyst was 99 %, and the yield of BTX reached 94.4 %. In conclusion, a poor toxicity resistance, high price, and high hydrogenation activity are disadvantages of noble metal catalysts. Future research may focus on enhancing the anti-poisoning ability of precious metals, increasing the life of noble metal catalysts, and modifying their hydrogenation activity. Non-noble metal catalysts have received more attention due to their good selectivity for BTX, low price, and high toxicity resistance; to further increase the yield of BTX, the support should have a certain structure and acidity to match with the metal. 3.3 Supports The supports also significantly affect the activity and selectivity of the catalysts. The supports used in hydrocracking usually include non-zeolites (such as γ-Al2O3 and ZrO2/SiO2) and molecular sieves (aluminum silicate materials such as Beta, USY, and MCM-41 molecular sieves). Non-zeolite catalysts have many problems. For example, the optimum amount of metal loading is used to determine the effects of crude oil upgrading, and catalyst calcination conditions have a huge influence on the acid properties of the support, dispersion of metal, and stability of the catalysts. Thus, non-zeolite catalysts have received little attention in recent years, and studies have shown that some kinds of bimetallic non-zeolite catalysts, such as Pd-Pt/ZrO2-SiO2 and CoMoS/ZrO2-SiO2, are the most stable non-zeolite catalysts for BTX production through diaromatic hydrocracking. Molecular sieves can provide acid sites for catalysts, which influence the reaction in two ways. On the one hand, isomerization reactions occur on the hydrogenation products of dicyclic aromatics from six-membered rings to five-membered rings, and the five-membered rings are further broken. On the other hand, the side chains of long-chain monocyclic aromatics are broken to generate light aromatics. The molecular sieves commonly used in the production of BTX are USY, HY, MCM-41, ITQ-21, ZSM-5, H-Beta, and MCM-22 [70,109,131,132]. Different molecular sieves have various pore structures, specific surface areas, and acid properties (including acid strength and type); thus, they also have different catalytic performances. In the hydrocracking reaction, a Brønsted acid is usually required. Sato et al. [133] used tetralin as a probe molecule to study the ring-opening reactions of aromatics. The results showed that the ring-opening of tetralin requires a relatively strong Brønsted acid. Arribas et al. [109,110] believed that the concentration of the Brønsted acid should not be too high and that reducing the concentration of the Brønsted acid could reasonably inhibit the secondary cracking or dealkylation reaction. Chareonpanich et al. [84] used Al2O3 to load Mo, W, Co-Mo, Ni-Mo, and Ni-W when hydrocracking PAHs to produce BTX. After a certain amount of USY was added, the number of Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst increased. Sato et al. [40] used NiW as the active phase, and tetralin was used as a probe molecule to study the ring-opening reaction of aromatics on the supports of USY, HY, and mordenite. The results showed that the conversion rate of tetralin decreases in the following order: USY > HY > mordenite, and the yield of BTX is in the order of USY > mordenite > HY. The USY support showed excellent performance in the hydrocracking of tetralin to produce BTX, which is due to the suitable amount of Brønsted acids in USY compared with the other two supports. It can be seen from the above studies that the hydrocracking of PAHs to produce BTX requires a strong and suitable concentration of Brønsted acid. The pore structure of the supports has a significant influence on the diffusion and shape selectivity of the reactants and products. Corma et al. [74] studied the influence of the support pore structure on the PAHs hydrocracking reaction. They found that on ZSM-5 and MCM-22 molecular sieves with a 10-element ring, reactant molecules could enter the pores; however, the diffusion of products with alkyl side chains was restricted after ring opening, so the reaction of secondary cracking occurred easily. Kim et al. [60] used ZSM-5-, Beta-, and USY-supported Ni2P as catalysts to study the hydrocracking reaction of naphthalene. The results showed that the Ni2P/Beta catalyst showed the highest yield of BTX due to its large pore structure. Mostad et al. [134] studied the conversion of decalin on different molecular sieves under the same conditions. The results showed that the conversion rate of decalin on the H–Y molecular sieve was the highest (90 %), while that on the H-ZSM-5 molecular sieve was the lowest (21 %). The activity order of the four supports is H–Y > H-MOR > H-FER > H-ZSM-5, and the pore sizes of the four molecular sieves are 0.74, 0.67 × 0.7, 0.64 and 0.54 × 0.56 nm, respectively, which indicates that the activity of the catalysts increases with the increase in pore size. Tang et al. [135] studied the catalytic effect of H–Y and H-ZSM-5 molecular sieves on the ring opening of phenanthrene at different temperatures. The results indicated that the BTX produced by the catalysts is mainly related to their two-dimensional structures (0.53 × 0.56 nm and 0.51 × 0.55 nm). At the same time, H–Y molecular sieves (pore size of 0.74 nm) have a higher selectivity for heavy aromatics because of the larger pore diameter and structure of the twelve-membered ring cage, which inhibits the over-cracking reaction of heavy aromatics and, in turn, increases the ability to resist coke [136]. Thus, the yield of BTX can be increased by molecular sieves with mesopore and macropore sizes. The size of the support particles also affected the selectivity of BTX. Nanocatalysts show better performance in terms of activity, selectivity, and stability. The use of nanoscale catalysts is beneficial for eliminating the influence of diffusion, reducing coking, and enhancing the stability of the catalyst [137,138]. Konno et al. [139] studied the effect of supports with nanoparticle size on the activity of the ring-opening reaction and the yield of BTX. For the catalyst with large particles of H-ZSM-5, the selectivity of BTX decreased from 40 to 20 %, and that for the nanoscale H-ZSM-5 catalyst increased from 30 to 35 % with a reaction time of 4.5 h. The results show that the large particle catalyst produces more coking products than does the nanocatalyst. Kim et al. [130] also agreed with this result. They used Ni2P supported on nano-sized Beta to treat 1-methylnaphalene to BTX at 380 °C and 6.0 MPa, and the nanocatalysts showed a better selectivity for BTX than did traditional catalysts with Beta molecular sieves, because the nano-sized Beta has abundant intercrystalline mesopores to provide a better dispersion for reactants and products, offering their proximity to the center of hydrogenation and cracking. The large specific surface area of the supports is conducive to the adsorption and desorption of reactants and products. Pujro et al. [140] studied the effect of microstructure on the hydrocracking of LCO using H–Y molecular sieves with different specific surface areas (243, 191, and 181 m2/g). The feed conversion on the H–Y molecular sieve with the largest specific surface area (243 m2/g) was the highest (30 %), while those for the other two types of H–Y were 25 % and 20 %, respectively. The selectivity of BTX also showed the same trend. Hybrid molecular sieves have attracted considerable attention for modifying the properties of supports because they have the advantages of different molecular sieves used in the reaction. Oh et al. [141] used hybrid molecular sieves to study the hydrocracking activity of LCO into light-aromatic-enriched BTX. The results showed that MoS/BYZ (80:10:10), which contained 10 wt% mesoporous H–Y, 80 wt% H-Beta, and 10 wt% H-ZSM-5, produced a high yield of BTX-rich light aromatics because of its strong acid strength (afforded by H–Y) and the ability to enhance the conversion efficiency of C11+ heavy aromatics (afforded by H-Beta and H-ZSM-5). Moreover, some researchers have developed new supports that resist the influence of nitrogen compounds on hydrocracking catalysts. Barbosa et al. [142] prepared a series of NiMo catalysts supported on Al-MCM-41 with different ratios of SiO2/Al2O3 to hydrocracking cumene, and they found that Al–MCM–41-based catalysts lost only 4–7 % of their activity to produce BTX when the nitrogen content in the feed was 150 ppm. The resistance to poisoning by nitrogen compounds is most likely related to the hydrodenitrification capability of these catalysts, and their Brønsted sites are of medium strength, which may be another reason. Corma et al. [143] also found that NiMo/MCM-41 catalysts showed higher hydrocracking activities for BTX production from naphthalene than did catalysts based on Al2O3 or USY molecular sieves in the presence of a nitrogen content of 2900 ppm. It seems that the MCM-41 molecular sieve has a high resistance to nitrogen compounds; however, the crystallinity of the MCM-41 molecular sieve is not very good, and lattice collapse occurs easily under roasting at high temperatures. Thus, the MCM-41 molecular sieve is not widely used in hydrocracking reactions. Based on the above studies, the supports used in hydrocracking di-aromatics should have a moderate number of Brønsted sites to obtain the ring-opening ability and to inhibit the secondary cracking or dealkylation reaction. However, the influence of the acid amount and strength of the catalyst on the hydrocracking reaction of LCO is still not clear at present, mainly because the hydrocracking reaction of LCO is a complex process, and the role of the acid center in each step of the acid catalytic reaction cannot be quantitatively determined. Moreover, LCO is a complicated system, and the adsorption of alkanes and cycloalkanes on acid sites leads to the low reactive activity of aromatics. In this situation, researchers should pay more attention to the competitive adsorption of aromatics and other components on acid sites. The pore structure of the support could also be modified to match with aromatics to maximize the yield of BTX. 3.4 Modification of supports To increase the yield of target products or maintain the stability of catalysts, approaches for adding other materials to the catalysts and treatment of supports are usually introduced in the preparation of catalysts. Researchers usually improve the selectivity of the target product by adjusting the acid properties and pore structure of the catalyst. Xin et al. [144] used a 0.2 mol/L NaOH solution to treat a ZSM-5 molecular sieve at 80 °C for 6 h to obtain meso-ZSM-5, which is usually called alkali treatment. The results showed that for the ring-opening selectivity of tetralin to produce alkylbenzene, which can be further cracked to BTX, the meso-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited a high value of 79 − 84 wt% selectivity for alkylbenzene. However, the ring-opening ability of tetralin on the ZSM-5 catalyst was much lower, at 45–63 wt% under the same conditions. The reasons for the improved performance of the meso-ZSM-5 catalyst are its large pore structure, good dispersion of products, and acid accessibility of the reactants. Ren et al. [145] used a fluorine–alkaline treatment to prepare mesoporous Y molecular sieves (USY-F-AT). They compared the hydrocracking ability of NiMo/(Al2O3 + USY) and NiMo/(Al2O3 + USY-F-AT) using naphthalene as a model compound. It was found that NiMo/(Al2O3 + USY-F-AT) showed a similar hydrogenation activity but much higher ring opening ability compared with NiMo/(Al2O3 + USY). The yield of ring opening products for NiMo/(Al2O3 + USY) was 7.6 wt% at 400 °C, and that for NiMo/(Al2O3 + USY-F-AT) could reach 26.2 wt% at the same temperature. Fluorination–alkaline treatment can increase the mesopore volume, pore diameter, and acid amount of the catalysts, especially Brønsted acid. Kim et al. [19] used a weak acid treatment to process nanopore Beta molecular sieves to reduce the acid amount by dealumination. They found that NiW supported on a dealuminated Beta molecular sieve exhibited the highest selectivity for ring-opening products due to its higher SiO2/Al2O3 ratio (around 55) and smaller acid amount than its parents. The yield of BTEX (where ‘E’ represents ethylbenzene) was 44.9 wt% after hydrocracking by the catalysts after acid treatment, while that of catalysts without acid treatment was 39.5 wt%. Other materials are usually introduced to modify the catalysts to disperse the active phase and reduce the acid strength, which can restrain the formation of carbon deposition and increase the yield of BTX. Lee et al. [146] found that the addition of K to a NiW/HY catalyst can moderate its acidity. The yield of BTEX can be increased by 8.3 wt% for the NiW/HY catalysts with the addition of 0.3 wt% K compared with that without K addition. Ardakani et al. [112] also found that K or Mg could improve the dispersion of Mo2C on HY, and K could also moderate the Brønsted acid of the catalyst. Through a modification by Mg or K, the conversion of naphthalene was reduced using the modified catalysts due to a carbon deposition on the Brønsted acid sites. Another study [147] agreed that the acidity of the catalysts was not influenced by the addition of Mg, whereas the addition of K decreased the acidity of the catalysts by 30 %. In addition, their research found that the addition of Mg and K could increase the hydrogenation activity of catalysts over naphthalene; however, the ring-opening selectivity to generate BTX was reduced compared with the original catalysts. Cheng et al. [148] studied the effect of water on the hydrogenation of naphthalene to tetralin using formic acid as the H2 and water source. The results showed that the addition of water effectively inhibited the formation of coke and increased the yield of tetralin. To maintain the stability of the catalysts, the addition of other materials to increase the dispersion of the active phase requires further research. Evidently, support modification is a direct way to change the acid properties and pore structure of the catalyst. Acid treatment, alkali treatment, and the addition of other materials are the conventional processes used to adjust the properties of the catalysts. However, these treatment methods are catalyst after-treatments, and it is difficult to efficiently obtain the properties of the catalysts in demand. It is more effective to synthesize molecular sieves or other materials according to the pore structure and acid properties, because the Si/Al, pore size, and channel structure can be effectively adjusted. Therefore, there may be more new molecular sieves and other materials applied in the hydrocracking of LCO to BTX in the next few years. 3.5 The interaction between metal and support Hydrocracking catalysts have an active phase and support to exert different functions. Because of a further understanding of the hydrocracking reaction, some researchers believe that to achieve a high feed conversion rate and high selectivity of BTX, it is necessary to promote the balance between the metal center and acid [149]. This includes both the balance of the amount and proximity of the metal center to the acid center. The yield of BTX could be improved by controlling the following areas [150]: (1) the hydrogenation activity of the metal (inhibiting the hydrocracking activity), (2) the acidity of the support for the cracking activity, and (3) the balance of metal and acid. A greater amount of metal loaded on the supports can usually obtain higher hydrogenation activity, but it could exert some influence on the support and increase the cost of catalysts. Many researchers have explored catalysts with highly dispersed metals to achieve high reactivity. In some ways, deposition-precipitation [151,152], equilibrium deposition filtration [153,154], chemical vapor deposition [155], and sonochemical [156], are used to achieve this purpose. However, a catalyst with a well-dispersed metal has a large defect, which is the strong interaction between the support and metal. The stacking form and sulfidation of metal are decreased by strong metal–acid interactions [157]. Thus, the hydrogenation activity of the catalysts is also inhibited. This is usually not a good way to reduce the acidity of the support because the hydrocracking activity of the catalyst may be decreased and a metal with a large particle size may be generated, resulting in a reduced amount of metal on the support [158]. It is still difficult to balance the activity of the metal and the support. A few researchers have studied this interaction and made some adjustments. Wu et al. [159] studied the metal − support balance and influence of metal on the yield of BTX, and they found that the interaction of metal − acid, ratio of metal − acid, and dispersion of metal exerted a significant effect on the hydrocracking activity of the catalysts. In addition, their research showed that a highly selective hydrogenation activity could be obtained by dispersing the metal oxides on the support, and the yield of BTX was dependent on the ratio of metal − acid. The interaction between the metal and support also influences the selective hydrogenation activity. A large amount of coke products or by-products may be obtained with an unsuitable ratio of metal to support. Xu et al. [160] prepared a NiMo/SiO2-Al2O3 hydrodesulfurization catalyst by synthesizing a new tungsten precursor. The results showed that the tungsten precursor could adjust the strength of the interaction between the metal and support, thus improving the dispersion of the metal on the surface of the support and regulating the catalytic performance of the catalyst. By adding ethylene glycol to a metal precursor solution to regulate the metal-support interaction, Qiu et al. [161] studied its influence on the hydrogenation of naphthalene. When the molar ratio of ethylene glycol to Ni atoms is 1, the interaction between the metal and support is appropriate, resulting in a high NiO dispersion (small particles) and many effective active sites; thus, naphthalene can be completely hydrogenated to produce decalin at 55 °C. Zhang et al. [162] studied the influence of metal-support interactions on the reaction performance using a monatomic catalyst of Pt/Carbon. They found that enhancing the surface acidity of the support is conducive to improving the metal-support interaction, inhibiting the sintering of metals, and reducing the hydrogenation activity of metals. In recent years, it has been difficult to prepare hydrocracking catalysts with a high hydrogenation activity on strong acid supports. Owing to the strong metal-support interaction, metal oxides are difficult to reduce, and the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst is inhibited [163]. The proximity between the center of the metal and the acid also has a strong influence on the distribution of products. As shown in Fig. 8 , the two active sites of the catalyst play different roles in 1-methylnaphthalene hydrocracking. If the centers of the metal are too close, over-hydrogenation of 1-methylnaphthalene will occur, leading to a low selectivity for BTX, and the dehydrogenation reaction results in a low conversion rate of 1-methylnaphthalene. However, few studies have focused on the proximity of two types of centers when hydrocracking LCO to produce BTX. Researchers should pay more attention to this topic in the future. Currently, there are many studies on hydrocracking catalysts, including the influence of metal characteristics (metal type, metal load, metal dispersity, etc.) on the hydrocracking activity and the influence of molecular sieve properties (acid type and pore structure, etc.) on cracking activity. However, it is not clear how the components, load, and dispersion of metals affect the selective hydrogenation ability of the catalyst. There are also few reports on how the LCO hydrocracking catalyst achieves a quantitative matching of the two types of active centers [111]. In addition, there are no studies on the structure-activity relationship between the mesoporous properties (including mesoporous size and volume) of mesoporous molecular sieves and the LCO hydrocracking reaction performance. The main reason is that LCO hydrocracking is a complex reaction process, and the yield of BTX is the result of the reaction of LCO on two active centers. It is difficult to judge the performance of the two active centers in each step of the reaction from the yield of BTX and the conversion rate of LCO; therefore, it is difficult to establish the structure-activity relationship between the properties of the catalyst and the reaction performance. More high technologies, such as synchrotron radiation, could be used to study the role of the two active centers in the hydrocracking of LCO to BTX. 4 Improved process conditions for hydrocracking and related technologies With the development of catalysts, researchers need to adjust the BTX production process to match the catalysts. The following sections detail the impact of each factor on the hydrocracking of di-aromatics. 4.1 Effect of temperature In the hydrocracking reaction, the reaction temperature is an important factor. The appropriate reaction temperature usually depends on the hydrogenation reaction and ring opening reaction, which is also related to other process parameters such as pressure, type of feedstock, and catalyst. It is acknowledged that the hydrogenation reaction is usually exothermic, whereas the ring-opening reaction is endothermic. Changes in temperature affect the chemical equilibrium and reaction rate of the two reactions [165]. From a thermodynamic perspective, an increase in temperature is beneficial to the endothermic reaction but not to the exothermic reaction; thus, a high temperature is beneficial to the ring-opening reaction rather than the hydrogenation reaction. Chareonpanich et al. [166] found that when the temperature increased from 400 to 600 °C at 5 MPa, the conversion rates of naphthalene, tetralin, and 2-methylnaphthalene on USY increased and even exceeded 100 % because LPG was generated. It is worth mentioning that the yield of BTX in the generated products was always lower than 50 %, and C1-C7 comprised the remainder of the products, which indicates that the cracking reaction dominates at high temperatures. A similar phenomenon was observed for the hydrocracking of tetralin and 2-methylnaphthalene. In another related study, Shin et al. [126] found that an increase in temperature (from 375 to 450 °C) can reduce the yield of alkylbenzenes and increase the yield of BTX when using H-ZSM-5 catalysts for hydrocracking tetralin. However, when the temperature was greater than 425 °C, the yield of BTX began to decrease. The reason was that the increase in temperature promoted the breakage of the alkyl chain of alkyl benzene, which is the cracking reaction; however, the tetralin hydrogenation reaction was restrained at high temperatures, leading to a reduction in the BTX yield. As mentioned above, the hydrogenation of methylnaphthalene is a reversible reaction, which means that the hydrogenated products will undergo a dehydrogenation reaction, which is an endothermic reaction; therefore, an increase in temperature will increase the amount of methylnaphthalene in the products. Miki et al. [77] used Ni-Mo/Al2O3 to study the effect of temperature on the distribution of products when hydrocracking 1-methylnaphthalene and 2-methylnaphthalene at 6 MPa. When the temperature was increased from 390 to 450 °C, the amount of hydrogenated product decreased, while that of the cracking product increased significantly. In addition, the yield of 1-methylnaphthalene in the products increased by nearly 15 wt%, and the same phenomenon was observed in the hydrocracking of 2-methylnaphthalene. Thus, at higher reaction temperatures, the hydrogenation of aromatics does not proceed smoothly, which has a significant influence on the product distribution. From the above studies, a suitable reaction temperature is closely related to the feed, catalysts, and thermodynamics. A relatively high temperature can increase the reaction rate of PAHs hydrocracking; however, the hydrogenation rate is restrained by thermodynamics, which may lead to excessive cracking and a decrease in the amount of MAHs. In addition, a low temperature not only decreases the reaction rate of the whole system but also reduces the hydrogenation activity of the catalysts, which is not ideal for treating PAHs to BTX. Many studies [167,168] indicated that the suitable reaction temperature is approximately 400 °C, and researchers could select this reaction temperature when developing new catalysts. 4.2 Effect of pressure Pressure is another important index of the hydrocracking process. Usually, the hydrogenation of PAHs is a reaction in which multiple molecules form a single molecule, so an increase in pressure will promote the hydrogenation reaction from the viewpoint of physical chemistry. However, excessively high pressures lead to the oversaturation of PAHs to form cycloalkanes. Gutierrez et al. [169] found that hydrogen pressures of 3.5 − 7.5 MPa could significantly affect the hydrocracking of LCO over Pt − Pd/HY. The yield of naphtha increased greatly with increasing pressure. However, the amount of aromatics decreased from 60 wt% to 30 wt% as the pressure increased, which proved that a large amount of the aromatics was hydrogenated. In another study, Ishigaki et al. [170] studied the hydrogenation of 1-methylnaphthalene on CoMo/Al2O3 under pressures of 3.1–7.5 MPa, and the results showed that the amount of methyl-tetralin decreased from 88 to 60 %, while that of methyl-decalin increased from 12 to 40 %, indicating that the 1-methylnaphthalene was completely saturated. Therefore, excessively high pressure is not desirable for producing BTX, because an excessive saturation of PAHs occurs and cycloalkanes are formed. Therefore, a certain pressure value is needed to ensure the saturation of one ring of di-cyclic aromatics, and the over-saturation of di-cyclic aromatics should be controlled. Researchers and producers can reasonably increase the reaction pressure to maintain an aromatic ring. 4.3 Effect of space velocity Space velocity is the flow rate of the feed into the reactor relative to the catalyst and can be represented as the liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) or weight hourly space velocity (WHSV). The former represents the volume ratio of the feed oil to the catalysts, and the latter is the mass ratio of the feed oil to the catalysts. The reciprocal of the space velocity is generally referred to as the residence time. Increasing the space velocity usually reduces the contact time between the feed and catalyst, which may decrease the production of secondary products. Upare et al. [171] studied the influence of space velocity on tetralin hydrocracking over CoMo/Beta, and the results showed that the yield of C1-C4 gas decreased from 60 to 20 % as the space velocity increased from 0.4 to 1.6 h−1, while the yield of MAHs increased from 33 to 60 %. It seems that an increase in the space velocity has a desirable effect on the production of BTX. However, the conversion rate of the feed will decrease while continuing to increase the space velocity due to an incomplete feed reaction on the catalysts, and the distribution of products will be changed. Gutierrez et al. [172] studied the effect of space velocity on LCO hydrocracking using a Pt-Pd/HY catalyst at 350 °C and 4.5 MPa. The results showed that the conversion rate of LCO declined from 84 to 2 % as the space velocity increased from 1 to 8 h-1. In addition, the content of aromatics in the gasoline fraction increased from 5 to 30 wt% with the increasing space velocity. Thus, to obtain a high yield of BTX, it is usually necessary to reasonably increase the space velocity; however, a high space velocity also means that less feed can be converted to BTX. To maintain the production and ensure the conversion rate, the catalyst volume (or reactor volume) needs to be increased, which is a relatively simple and beneficial retrofit solution. As a suggestion, the optimal conditions for hydrocracking LCO to produce BTX are suggested as temperature (370–450 °C), pressure (4–10 MPa), and space time (0.5–2 h−1). 4.4 Hydrocracking technology Currently, there are several worldwide technologies for converting aromatics in LCO into light aromatics by hydrocracking reactions. The technologies currently used in hydrocracking inferior diesel to produce BTX are listed in Table 5 . As shown in Table 5, the technologies are mainly distributed in America (LCO-X technology [173,174]), Canada (ARO technology [175]), and China (FD2G [176], LTAG, and BLG technologies). Of these, the LTAG and BLG technologies have not been introduced internationally. The feedstocks for these technologies are typical inferior diesel, including LCO and FCC diesel. For catalysts used in these technologies, the ARO technology adopts noble-metal Pd as the active phase, which is different from other technologies. Ni, Mo, and W are generally used as active components in the other four technologies. It is worth mentioning that Fe is used as the active phase for LCO-X technology, and the speculation is that the aim of this method is to reduce the cost of catalysts. The supports for these technologies are molecular sieves such as Y and USY, which can afford macropores and strong Brønsted acids on the catalysts. The optimal conditions for BTX production from LCO hydrocracking conform to the conditions described in the section above. The temperature range is 350–420 °C. The optimal pressure is in the range of 3–10 MPa, and the space velocity is relatively low (0.6–10 h−1). As for the products, the LCO-X technology from UOP cooperation has the highest BTX yield (approximately 44 %). The RLG and FD2G technologies also have favorable BTX yields of 32 % and 35 %, respectively, while the ARO and LTAG technologies are at a disadvantage. Although these technologies have been widely applied in the industry for many years, they also have some problems. The LCO-X technology has a high yield of BTX, but the entire operation process is complex, so the equipment cost and energy consumption are large. The ARO technology is simpler than the LCO-X technology; thus, the equipment investment is small. However, precious metals with high prices are used as the active phase in this process. Moreover, the yield of BTX in the products is relatively low, and the yield of alkanes in liquid products is relatively high, which results in poor economic benefits. The RLG and LCO-X technologies have the same problem; that is, they require catalytic reforming to obtain a higher yield of light aromatics; thus, it also has a complicated process, high equipment cost, and high energy consumption. As for the other two technologies, the LTAG technology has a low yield of BTX, and the main purpose of the FD2G technology is to produce high-quality diesel and by-product BTX, so the yield of BTX is actually low. In summary, the technologies have some problems, and the companies could make some improvements in these areas. In addition to these industrial technologies, many researchers have proposed hydrocracking processes for BTX using inferior diesel, as shown in Table 6 . It can be seen that the feed is usually LCO, and the catalysts are bifunctional catalysts with different compositions. For the metal of the catalysts, noble metals such as Pt and Pd are widely used due to their high hydrogenation activity, but they will increase the cost of catalysts. Various supports are adopted by these processes, and it is speculated that researchers are about to utilize the suitable pore structures and acidity of the different supports, but there is a huge difference in their costs. Because of the use of different catalysts, the optimal conditions for these processes are different, and most of them are in the range of our recommended conditions. In addition, some issues block the industrialization of these processes, such as low BTX yield, high catalyst cost, and utilization of model LCO. If these problems can be solved effectively, these processes can be industrial in the future. 5 Current problems and the development of diesel hydrocracking The current technologies for using inferior diesel to produce fuel oil are very mature; however, the consumption of refined oil will reach its peak, so the production of BTX has become a hot direction for diesel hydrocracking. However, there are still some problems in this area, such as product property issues and increased production costs [97,100,103,183,184]. First, hydrocracking catalysts should be improved. For the current hydrocracking technologies, part of the inferior diesel is returned to the hydrocracking unit because of the low one-way conversion rate, resulting in a relatively large recovery, and in turn, the economic benefits are affected. Thus, the low conversion rate of feed and low selectivity for BTX hinder the hydrocracking technology for inferior diesel. It is still urgent to modify the catalysts and adjust the optimal conditions to handle these problems. On the one hand, the modification of catalysts can effectively improve their hydrogenation activity by reducing the particle size of the metal and creating a mesoporous structure to increase the surface area of the support. On the other hand, a support with a strong Brønsted acid can enable the hydrocracking activity of the catalyst. As advice, the work on catalysts could be dedicated to the following areas in the coming years: (I) create a specific architecture to expose high-density surface active sites and increase the specific surface area to obtain better hydrogenation, (II) use supports with special mesopore channel structures to accelerate the reactant diffusion and increase the shape-selectivity for BTX, thereby reducing kinetic reaction obstacles and increasing the selectivity of BTX; (III) synthesize new molecular sieves or combine different molecular sieves to adjust the electronic configuration and optimize the acid properties of the catalyst surface, and (IV) further study the match relationship between the metal and supports to coordinate the hydrogenation and hydrocracking activity. In addition, the hydrocracking process should be improved. Despite the application of these catalysts in industrial fields, there are still some problems and challenges in the process. Owing to the treatment of the full fraction of diesel in some technologies, saturated hydrocarbon components with high cetane numbers undergo cracking reactions, resulting in a high yield of gas by-products and high hydrogen consumption. The cost of diesel hydrocracking is first reflected in the hydrogen consumption. Moreover, the over-hydrogenation of PAHs leads to a reduction in BTX production and increases the hydrogen consumption and cost. It is worth mentioning that the aromatic content in the catalytic reforming technology product can reach more than 95 %; thus, aromatic extraction technology is not needed. However, owing to the low yield of light aromatics in the liquid product, aromatic extraction is still necessary for hydrocracking technology. These problems affect the economy of the technology and hinder its large-scale application. To address the problem of high hydrogen consumption, researchers can improve the process in several areas. First, hydrocracking devices are usually coupled with a hydrotreatment device owing to the hydrocracking catalyst poisoning by nitrogen compounds. The entire procedure is complicated and expensive. Companies can develop high-nitrogen compound-resistance catalysts to remove the hydrotreatment device, which can significantly reduce the cost of the entire process. Second, despite the improved hydrogenation activity of the catalysts, the over-hydrogenation of PAHs will inevitably occur, which will increase the hydrogen consumption and result in the loss of PAHs. The main direction for researchers is still to improve existing bifunctional catalysts or develop new catalysts. Finally, in addition to the cost of BTX hydrocracking catalysts, the low conversion rate of feeds and selectivity of BTX are other major obstacles for BTX production. A high LCO conversion rate also requires suitable reaction process conditions such as temperature and pressure; therefore, companies must upgrade existing equipment, which may also increase certain costs. Finally, the model compounds used in hydrocracking research are usually pure components. However, LCO has thousands of components. Different components may be absorbed on the metal and acid centers and then react. In addition, hydrogenated products such as tetralin and alkylbenzene will also absorb on the two kinds of centers, which leads to a low reactivity of the fresh feeds. Another direction that researchers should consider is to increase the adsorption selectivity of PAHs on the active center. In the future, more advanced technologies, such as the aid and application of computational chemistry tools, can be applied to analyze all the types of aromatics in LCO and their reaction activity. This could help to deepen the understanding of the reactions and pathways of complicated systems and obtain the development of more efficient catalysts by balancing the properties of the active phase and surmounting current shortcomings. 6 Conclusion With the consumption peak of diesel and the impact of new energy sources, the utilization of excessive diesel, especially inferior diesel such as LCO, has attracted increasing attention. For the treatment of LCO, it is desirable to produce chemical materials, such as BTX, because their demand is sustainable for a few years. The hydrocracking reaction mechanisms and pathways of naphthalene, alkylnaphthalene, and tetralin in LCO to produce BTX have been well researched for many years. In addition, bifunctional catalysts have been developed to hydrocrack PAHs to BTX. However, the relationship between the amount of acid and the active phase in the catalysts has attracted little attention, and the interaction of metal and supports, the structure of pores, and the influence of surface properties on the hydrocracking reaction have not been well studied. The competitive reaction of each component in LCO on the active center of the catalyst is not clear. Although a large number of experiments have been conducted to explore the optimal conditions for hydrocracking naphthalene, there are few studies on the kinetics of hydrocracking inferior diesel, and the technologies of hydrocracking for BTX production need to be improved. The development of nitrogen-compound-resistant catalysts with excellent performance to reduce the process energy and hydrogen consumptions and increase the selectivity of BTX is the future development direction of LCO hydrocracking. Under the condition of increasingly tight petroleum resources, the utilization of inferior diesel to produce BTX will attract increasing attention in the next decade. coredata.dc:description: With the peak in diesel consumption and the impact of new energy in the coming years, research will be focused on the treatment of excess diesel. In addition, low carbon aromatics such as benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) are important chemical raw materials that will be in high demand in the next few years but are still in short supply. Thus, many researchers have proposed the use of excess diesel, especially the inferior diesel-like light cycle oil (LCO) to produce BTX. The hydrocracking process is typically used to convert LCO to BTX. To provide some guidance on this topic, this review summarizes the typical group compositions in LCO from different refineries, hydrocracking reaction mechanisms of aromatics and cycloalkanes in LCO, hydrocracking catalysts, improved hydrocracking conditions, related hydrocracking technologies, and future developments in the production of BTX. The amount of aromatics with different ring numbers in LCO has been clearly analyzed, and their part types have also been studied. However, some complex types of aromatics in LCO remain unknown. In addition, the hydrocracking mechanisms and pathways of aromatics in LCO to produce BTX have garnered great attention since the 1990s. Based on this, hydrocracking catalysts and related technologies have been developed by many institutions and corporations to convert aromatics to BTX; however, there are still some problems including an insufficient selectivity of BTX, low yield of liquid products, and excessive energy consumption. In the future, more advanced technologies can be applied to analyze all types of aromatics in LCO, which, along with the aid and application of computational chemistry tools, could help deepen the understanding of the reaction pathways of aromatics and develop more efficient catalysts by balancing the properties of the active phase and supporting the surmounting of current shortcomings. Owing to this high value utilization of inferior diesel, the upcoming problem of diesel surplus can be solved effectively, and the utilization of LCO to produce BTX is one possible path.
coredata.dc:title: High value utilization of inferior diesel for BTX production: Mechanisms, catalysts, conditions and challenges
